member.remarks: Most of these codes are referenced somewhere else in the documentation when they are relevant to methods.

member.summary:
the PhotonPeer is connected.

member.remarks:
The server could be down / not running or the client has no network or a misconfigured DNS.
See {@link PhotonListener#OnStatusChanged}*

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonPeerListener
member.summary: Callback interface for the Photon client side. Must be provided to a new PhotonPeer in its constructor.
member.remarks: These methods are used by your PhotonPeer instance to keep your app updated. Read each method's description and check out the samples to see how to use them.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonPeerListener.DebugReturn(ExitGames.Client.Photon.DebugLevel,System.String)
member.summary: Provides textual descriptions for various error conditions and noteworthy situations. In cases where the application needs to react, a call to OnStatusChanged is used. OnStatusChanged gives "feedback" to the game, DebugReturn provies human readable messages on the background.
member.remarks: All debug output of the library will be reported through this method. Print it or put it in a buffer to use it on-screen. Use PhotonPeer.DebugOut to select how verbose the output is.
member.param: DebugLevel (severity) of the message.
Debug text. Print to System.Console or screen.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonPeerListener.OnOperationResponse(ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse)
member.summary: Callback method which gives you (async) responses for called operations.
member.remarks:
Similar to method-calling, operations can have a result. Because operation-calls are non-blocking and executed on the server, responses are provided after a roundtrip as call to this method.
Example: Trying to create a room usually succeeds but can fail if the room's name is already in use (room names are their IDs).
This method is used as general callback for all operations. Each response corresponds to a certain "type" of operation by its OperationCode.
member.param: The response to an operation\-call.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonPeerListener.OnStatusChanged(ExitGames.Client.Photon.StatusCode)
member.summary: OnStatusChanged is called to let the game know when asynchronous actions finished or when errors happen.
member.remarks:
Not all of the many StatusCode values will apply to your game. Example: If you don't use encryption, the respective status changes are never made.
The values are all part of the StatusCode enumeration and described value-by-value.
member.param: A code to identify the situation.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonPeerListener.OnEvent(ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData)
member.summary: Called whenever an event from the Photon Server is dispatched.
member.remarks:
Events are used for communication between clients and allow the server to update clients anytime. The creation of an event is often triggered by an operation (called by this client or an other).
Each event carries a Code plus optional content in its Parameters. Your application should identify which content to expect by the event's Code.
Events can be defined and modified server-side.
If you use the LoadBalancing api as basis, several events like EvJoin and EvLeave are pre-defined. The LoadBalancing api provides the EventCode and ParameterCode classes for pre-defined events.
Photon also allows you to come up with custom events on the fly, purely client-side. To do so, use OpRaiseEvent.
Events are incoming messages and as such buffered in the peer. Calling PhotonPeer.DispatchIncomingCommands will call IPhotonPeerListener.OnEvent, to hand over received events.
PhotonPeer.ReuseEventInstance is an option to optimize memory usage by reusing one EventData instance.
member.param: The event currently being dispatched.

member.summary: Provides the protocol string, of the current PhotonPeer.SerializationProtocolType to be used for WebSocket connections.
member.remarks:
Any WebSocket wrapper could access this to get the desired binary protocol for the connection. Some WebSocket implementations use a static value of the same name and need to be updated.
The value is not cached and each call will create the needed string on the fly.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonSocket.TryParseAddress(System.String,System.String@,System.UInt16@,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: Separates the given address into address (host name or IP) and port. Port must be included after colon!
member.remarks:
This method expects any address to include a port. The final ':' in addressAndPort has to separate it. IPv6 addresses have multiple colons and must use brackets to separate address from port.
Examples: ns.exitgames.com:5058 http://[2001:db8:1f70::999:de8:7648:6e8]:100/ [2001:db8:1f70::999:de8:7648:6e8]:100 See: http://serverfault.com/questions/205793/how-can-one-distinguish-the-host-and-the-port-in-an-ipv6-url

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonSocket.GetIpAddresses(System.String)
member.summary: Wraps a DNS call to provide an array of addresses, sorted to have the IPv6 ones first.
member.remarks: This skips a DNS lookup, if the hostname is an IPv4 address. Then only this address is used as is. The DNS lookup may take a while, so it is recommended to do this in a thread. Also, it may fail entirely.
member.returns:
IPAddress array for hostname, sorted to put any IPv6 addresses first.
If the DNS lookup fails, HandleException(StatusCode.ExceptionOnConnect) gets called and null returned. Then the socket should not attempt to connect.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonSocket.GetIpAddress(System.String)
member.summary: Returns null or the IPAddress representing the address, doing Dns resolution if needed.
member.remarks: Only returns IPv4 or IPv6 adresses, no others.
member.param: The string address of a server (hostname or IP).
member.returns: IPAddress for the string address or null, if the address is neither IPv4, IPv6 or some hostname that could be resolved.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.ITrafficRecorder.Record(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Int16,ExitGames.Client.Photon.IPhotonSocket)
member.summary: Implement to record network traffic. Called by PhotonPeer for each UDP message sent and received.
member.remarks:
The buffer will not contain Ethernet Header, IP, UDP level data. Only the payload received by the client.
It is advised to not use NetworkSimulation when recording traffic. The recording is done on the timing of actual receive- and send-calls and internal simulation would offset the timing.

Length of the network data.
Indicates incoming (true) or outgoing (false) traffic.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.NetworkSimulationSet
member.summary: A set of network simulation settings, enabled (and disabled) by PhotonPeer.IsSimulationEnabled.
member.remarks:
For performance reasons, the lag and jitter settings can't be produced exactly. In some cases, the resulting lag will be up to 20ms bigger than the lag settings. Even if all settings are 0, simulation will be used. Set PhotonPeer.IsSimulationEnabled to false to disable it if no longer needed.
All lag, jitter and loss is additional to the current, real network conditions. If the network is slow in reality, this will add even more lag. The jitter values will affect the lag positive and negative, so the lag settings describe the medium lag even with jitter. The jitter influence is: [-jitter..+jitter]. Packets "lost" due to OutgoingLossPercentage count for BytesOut and LostPackagesOut. Packets "lost" due to IncomingLossPercentage count for BytesIn and LostPackagesIn.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer
member.summary: Instances of the PhotonPeer class are used to connect to a Photon server and communicate with it.
member.remarks:
A PhotonPeer instance allows communication with the Photon Server, which in turn distributes messages to other PhotonPeer clients.
An application can use more than one PhotonPeer instance, which are treated as separate users on the server. Each should have its own listener instance, to separate the operations, callbacks and events.

member.remarks: This value was used to get/set the initial capacities of command-lists. These grow on demand but knowing their capacity is of very limited use. Also, various command-lists grow their capacity independent from one another.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SocketImplementationConfig
member.summary: Optional definition of IPhotonSocket type per ConnectionProtocol.
member.remarks:
Several platforms have special Socket implementations and slightly different APIs. Customizing the SocketImplementationConfig helps to accomodate this. By default, UDP and TCP have socket implementations assigned.
If a native socket plugin is available set the SocketNativeSource class as Type definition here.
You only need to set the SocketImplementationConfig once, after creating a PhotonPeer and before connecting. If you switch the TransportProtocol, the correct implementation is being used.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SocketImplementation
member.summary: Can be used to read the IPhotonSocket implementation at runtime (before connecting).
member.remarks: Use the SocketImplementationConfig to define which IPhotonSocket is used per ConnectionProtocol.

member.name: E:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.OnDisconnectMessage
member.summary: Called when the client received a Disconnect Message from the server. Signals an error and provides a message to debug the case.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.ReuseEventInstance
member.summary: Option to make the PhotonPeer reuse a single EventData instance for all incoming events.
member.remarks:
This reduces memory garbage. If enabled, the event provided via OnEvent(EventData photonEvent) is invalid once the callback finished. That event's content will get modified. Typically this is not a problem as events are rarely cached.
Changing this value acquires the same lock that DispatchIncomingCommands() uses.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.UseByteArraySlicePoolForEvents
member.summary: Enables a deserialization optimization for incoming events. Defaults to false.
member.remarks:
When enabled, byte-arrays in incoming Photon events are deserialized into pooled ByteArraySlice instances (wrappers for byte[]). This improves the memory footprint for receiving byte-arrays in events.
When used, you have to release the (pooled) ByteArraySlice instances.
Adjust your handling of EventData accordingly:
The ByteArraySlice.Buffer will usually be bigger than the send/received byte-array. Check the ByteArraySlice.Count and read only the actually received bytes. The Buffer is reused and not cleared. The Offset will be 0 for incoming events.
Important: While the peer will acquire the ByteArraySlice and passes it to OnEvent, the game code has to call ByteArraySlice.Release() when the slice is no longer needed.
Send either byte[], ArraySegment or use the ByteArraySlicePool to acquire ByteArraySlices to send.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.ByteArraySlicePool
member.summary: Instance of a ByteArraySlicePool. UseByteArraySlicePoolForEvents defines if this PhotonPeer is using the pool for deserialization of byte[] in Photon events.
member.remarks:
ByteArraySlice is a serializable datatype of the Photon .Net client library. It helps avoid allocations by being pooled and (optionally) used in incoming Photon events (see: UseByteArraySlicePoolForEvents).
You can also use the pool to acquire ByteArraySlice instances for serialization. RaiseEvent will auto-release all ByteArraySlice instances passed in.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SendInCreationOrder
member.summary: This debug setting enables a new send-ordering for commands. Defaults to true and commands are sent in the order they are created. Set to false to use Enet ordering.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SequenceDeltaLimitResends
member.summary: Skips resending (individual) commands if their reliable sequence number is this amount larger than the highest acknowledged sequence number.
member.remarks: This puts focus on resending commands that are older and are needed on the receiver side to dispatch commands. It queues more on the client side than on the server. Affects only reliable UDP (based on enet).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SequenceDeltaLimitSends
member.summary: Skips sending reliable and unreliable commands if their reliable sequence number is this amount larger than the highest acknowledged sequence number.
member.remarks: This puts focus on resending commands that are older and are needed on the receiver side to dispatch commands. It queues more on the client side than on the server. Affects only reliable UDP (based on enet).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.MessageBufferPoolTrim(System.Int32)

member.remarks: The MessageBufferPool is a Queue<StreamBuffer> for performance reasons. This methods dequeues from the MessageBufferPool to get the Count equal to countOfBuffers, then it calls MessageBufferPool.TrimExcess().
member.param: New size of the pool. Clears the pool if <= 0.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.ChannelCount
member.summary: Gets / sets the number of channels available in UDP connections with Photon. Photon Channels are only supported for UDP. The default ChannelCount is 2. Channel IDs start with 0 and 255 is a internal channel.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.EnableEncryptedFlag
member.summary: Enables the client so send the "encrypted" flag on secure connections. Incompatible with Server SDK 4.x.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.CrcEnabled
member.summary: While not connected, this controls if the next connection(s) should use a per-package CRC checksum.
member.remarks:
While turned on, the client and server will add a CRC checksum to every sent package. The checksum enables both sides to detect and ignore packages that were corrupted during transfer. Corrupted packages have the same impact as lost packages: They require a re-send, adding a delay and could lead to timeouts.
Building the checksum has a low processing overhead but increases integrity of sent and received data. Packages discarded due to failed CRC cecks are counted in PhotonPeer.PacketLossByCrc.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.PacketLossByCrc
member.summary: Count of packages dropped due to failed CRC checks for this connection.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.PacketLossByChallenge
member.summary: Count of packages dropped due to wrong challenge for this connection.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SentReliableCommandsCount
member.summary: Gets the count of sent but not yet acknowledged commands (for UDP connections).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.ResentReliableCommands
member.summary: Count of commands that got repeated (due to local repeat-timing before an ACK was received).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SentCountAllowance
member.summary: Number of send retries before a peer is considered lost/disconnected. Default: 7.
member.remarks:
The initial timeout countdown of a command is calculated by the current roundTripTime + 4 * roundTripTimeVariance. Please note that the timeout span until a command will be resent is not constant, but based on the roundtrip time at the initial sending, which will be doubled with every failed retry.
DisconnectTimeout and SentCountAllowance are competing settings: either might trigger a disconnect on the client first, depending on the values and Roundtrip Time.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.InitialResendTimeMax
member.summary: Caps the initial timing for repeats of reliable commands. In milliseconds. Default: 400ms.
member.remarks:
Unless acknowledged, reliable commands are repeated initially after: current roundTripTime + 4 * roundTripTimeVariance.
As this value can be very high when there was exceptional lag, InitialResendTimeMax makes sure that commands get repeated several times before they may trigger a timeout.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.TimePingInterval
member.summary: Sets the time between pings being sent automatically. They measure the roundtrip time and keep connections from closing. Default: 1000.
member.remarks:
For Photon's reliable UDP connections, pings are skipped if any reliable command was sent during the specified TimePingInterval. Any reliable command is used to update the RoundTripTime and RoundTripTimeVariance.
When using TCP and WebSockets, the ping is of interest to measure the roundtrip and to keep a connection open, should nothing else With those two protocols, the ping is used to update the RoundTripTime and RoundTripTimeVariance.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.DisconnectTimeout
member.summary: Time in milliseconds before any sent reliable command triggers a timeout disconnect, unless acknowledged by the receiver. Default: 10000.
member.remarks:
DisconnectTimeout is not an exact value for a timeout. The exact timing of the timeout depends on the frequency of Service() calls and the roundtrip time. Commands sent with long roundtrip-times and variance are checked less often for re-sending.
DisconnectTimeout and SentCountAllowance are competing settings: either might trigger a disconnect on the client first, depending on the values and Roundtrip Time.
Default: 10000 ms. Maximum setting: 65535. Setting a negative value will apply the default timeout.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.ServerTimeInMilliSeconds
member.summary: Approximated Environment.TickCount value of server (while connected).
member.remarks:
UDP: The server's timestamp is automatically fetched after connecting (once). This is done internally by a command which is acknowledged immediately by the server. TCP: The server's timestamp fetched with each ping but set only after connecting (once).
The approximation will be off by +/- 10ms in most cases. Per peer/client and connection, the offset will be constant (unless FetchServerTimestamp() is used). A constant offset should be better to adjust for. Unfortunately there is no way to find out how much the local value differs from the original.
The approximation adds RoundtripTime / 2 and uses this.LocalTimeInMilliSeconds to calculate in-between values (this property returns a new value per tick).
The value sent by Photon equals Environment.TickCount in the logic layer.
member.value: 0 until connected. While connected, the value is an approximation of the server's current timestamp.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.LocalMsTimestampDelegate
member.summary: This setter for the (local-) timestamp delegate replaces the default Environment.TickCount with any equal function.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.ConnectionTime
member.summary: The internally used per PhotonPeer time value.
member.remarks:
Returns the integer part of a Stopwatch ElapsedMilliseconds value. If the PhotonPeer runs continuously the ClientTime will increment from zero to Int32..::.MaxValue for approximately 24.9 days, then jump to Int32..::.MinValue (a negative number), then increment back to zero during the next 24.9 days.
It is recommended to use this int only for delta times, to avoid handling the overflow.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.LastSendAckTime
member.summary: The last ConnectionTime value, when some ACKs were sent out by this client.
member.remarks: Only applicable to UDP connections.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.LastSendOutgoingTime
member.summary: The last ConnectionTime value, when SendOutgoingCommands actually checked outgoing queues to send them. Must be connected.
member.remarks: Available for UDP and TCP connections.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.LongestSentCall
member.summary: Measures the maximum milliseconds spent in PhotonSocket.Send().

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.RoundTripTime
member.summary: Time until a reliable command is acknowledged by the server.
member.remarks:
The value measures network latency and for UDP it includes the server's ACK-delay (setting in config). In TCP, there is no ACK-delay, so the value is slightly lower (if you use default settings for Photon).
RoundTripTime is updated constantly. Every reliable command will contribute a fraction to this value.
This is also the approximate time until a raised event reaches another client or until an operation result is available.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.RoundTripTimeVariance

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.LastRoundTripTime

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.MaximumTransferUnit
member.summary: The Maximum Trasfer Unit (MTU) defines the (network-level) packet-content size that is guaranteed to arrive at the server in one piece. The Photon Protocol uses this size to split larger data into packets and for receive-buffers of packets.
member.remarks: This value affects the Packet-content. The resulting UDP packages will have additional headers that also count against the package size (so it's bigger than this limit in the end) Setting this value while being connected is not allowed and will throw an Exception. member.summary: Starts connecting to the given Photon server. Non-blocking.
member.remarks: Connecting to the Photon server is done asynchronous. Unless an error happens right away (and this returns false), wait for the call of IPhotonPeerListener.OnStatusChanged.
member.param: Address of a Photon server as IP:port or hostname. WebSocket connections must contain a scheme (ws:// or wss://).
The ID of the app to use. Typically this is a guid (for the Photon Cloud). Max 32 characters.
Optional custom data to be used by server during peer creation. If used for authentication, the server is able to reject a client without creating a peer. Must be a serializable data type of Photon.
Custom data to send to the server in the Init request. Might be used to identify a client / user.
member.returns: True if a connection attempt will be made. False if some error could be detected early-on.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.Connect(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts connecting to the given Photon server. Non-blocking.
member.remarks: Connecting to the Photon server is done asynchronous. Unless an error happens right away (and this returns false), wait for the call of IPhotonPeerListener.OnStatusChanged.
member.param: Address of a Photon server as IP:port or hostname. WebSocket connections must contain a scheme (ws:// or wss://).
Optional address of a proxy server. Only used by WebSocket connections. Set null to use none.
The ID of the app to use. Typically this is a guid (for the Photon Cloud). Max 32 characters.

Optional Photon token data to be used by server during peer creation. If used for authentication, the server is able to reject a client without creating a peer. Must be of type string or byte[] (as provided by server).
Custom data to send to the server in the Init request. Might be used to identify a client / user.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.Disconnect
member.summary: This method initiates a mutual disconnect between this client and the server.
member.remarks:
Calling this method does not immediately close a connection. Disconnect lets the server know that this client is no longer listening. For the server, this is a much faster way to detect that the client is gone but it requires the client to send a few final messages.
On completion, OnStatusChanged is called with the StatusCode.Disconnect.
If the client is disconnected already or the connection thread is stopped, then there is no callback.
The default server logic will leave any joined game and trigger the respective event.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.StopThread
member.summary: This method immediately closes a connection (pure client side) and ends related listening Threads.
member.remarks: Unlike Disconnect, this method will simply stop to listen to the server. Udp connections will timeout. If the connections was open, this will trigger a callback to OnStatusChanged with code StatusCode.Disconnect.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.FetchServerTimestamp
member.summary: This will fetch the server's timestamp and update the approximation for property ServerTimeInMilliseconds.
member.remarks:
The server time approximation will NOT become more accurate by repeated calls. Accuracy currently depends on a single roundtrip which is done as fast as possible.
The command used for this is immediately acknowledged by the server. This makes sure the roundtrip time is low and the timestamp + rountriptime / 2 is close to the original value.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.EstablishEncryption
member.summary: This method creates a public key for this client and exchanges it with the server.
member.remarks:
Encryption is not instantly available but calls OnStatusChanged when it finishes. Check for StatusCode EncryptionEstablished and EncryptionFailedToEstablish.
Calling this method sets IsEncryptionAvailable to false. This method must be called before the "encrypt" parameter of OpCustom can be used.
member.returns: If operation could be enqueued for sending

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.InitDatagramEncryption(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes Datagram Encryption. Optionally, the EncryptorType is being used, if set.
member.param: Secret used to cipher udp packets.
Secret used for authentication of udp packets.
Sets if enet Sequence Numbers will be randomized or not. Preferably should be true.
Sets if the chaining mode should be CBC (false, default) or GCM (true). GCM mode is only available with a native encryption plugin.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.InitPayloadEncryption(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Photon's Payload Encryption secret may be set by a response from the server.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.Service
member.summary: This method excutes DispatchIncomingCommands and SendOutgoingCommands in your application Thread-context.
member.remarks:
The Photon client libraries are designed to fit easily into a game or application. The application is in control of the context (thread) in which incoming events and responses are executed and has full control of the creation of UDP/TCP packages.
Sending packages and dispatching received messages are two separate tasks. Service combines them into one method at the cost of control. It calls DispatchIncomingCommands and SendOutgoingCommands.
Call this method regularly (2..20 times a second).
This will Dispatch ANY remaining buffered responses and events AND will send queued outgoing commands. Fewer calls might be more effective if a device cannot send many packets per second, as multiple operations might be combined into one package.
member.example:
You could replace Service by:
while (DispatchIncomingCommands()); //Dispatch until everything is Dispatched... SendOutgoingCommands(); //Send a UDP/TCP package with outgoing messages

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SendOutgoingCommands
member.summary: Creates and sends a UDP/TCP package with outgoing commands (operations and acknowledgements). Also called by Service().
member.remarks:
As the Photon library does not create any UDP/TCP packages by itself. Instead, the application fully controls how many packages are sent and when. A tradeoff, an application will lose connection, if it is no longer calling SendOutgoingCommands or Service.
If multiple operations and ACKs are waiting to be sent, they will be aggregated into one package. The package fills in this order: ACKs for received commands A "Ping" - only if no reliable data was sent for a while Starting with the lowest Channel-Nr: Reliable Commands in channel Unreliable Commands in channel
This gives a higher priority to lower channels.
A longer interval between sends will lower the overhead per sent operation but increase the internal delay (which adds "lag").
Call this 2..20 times per second (depending on your target platform).
member.returns: The if commands are not yet sent. Udp limits it's package size, Tcp doesnt.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.DispatchIncomingCommands
member.summary: Dispatching received messages (commands), causes callbacks for events, responses and state changes within a IPhotonPeerListener.
member.remarks:
DispatchIncomingCommands only executes a single received command per call. If a command was dispatched, the return value is true and the method should be called again.
This method is called by Service() until currently available commands are dispatched. In general, this method should be called until it returns false. In a few cases, it might make sense to pause dispatching (if a certain state is reached and the app needs to load data, before it should handle new events).
The callbacks to the peer's IPhotonPeerListener are executed in the same thread that is calling DispatchIncomingCommands. This makes things easier in a game loop: Event execution won't clash with painting objects or the game logic.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.SendOperation(System.Byte,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Byte,System.Object},ExitGames.Client.Photon.SendOptions)
member.summary: Prepares your operation (code and parameters) to be sent to the Photon Server with specified SendOptions.
member.remarks:
This method serializes and enqueues the operation right away while the actual sending happens later. To be able to aggregate operations/messages, the Photon client sends packages only when you call SendOutgoingCommands().
The sendOptions specify how the operation gets sent exactly. Keep in mind that some transport protocols don't support unreliable or unsequenced transport. In that case, the sendOptions might be ignored.
The operationCode must be known by the server's logic or won't be processed. In almost all cases, sending an operation will result in a OperationResponse (see: IPhotonPeerListener.OnOperationResponse).
member.param: Operations are handled by their byte\-typed code. The codes are defined in the Realtime API (a.k.a. LoadBalancing API).
Containing parameters as key\-value pair. The key is byte\-typed, while the value is any serializable datatype.
Wraps up DeliveryMode (reliability), Encryption and Channel values for sending.
member.returns: If operation could be enqueued for sending.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.PhotonPeer.RegisterType(System.Type,System.Byte,ExitGames.Client.Photon.SerializeMethod,ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeserializeMethod)
member.summary: Registers new types/classes for de/serialization and the fitting methods to call for this type.
member.remarks:
SerializeMethod and DeserializeMethod are complementary: Feed the product of serializeMethod to the constructor, to get a comparable instance of the object.
After registering a Type, it can be used in events and operations and will be serialized like built-in types.
member.param: Type (class) to register.
A byte-code used as shortcut during transfer of this Type.
Method delegate to create a byte[] from a customType instance.
Method delegate to create instances of customType's from byte[].
member.returns: If the Type was registered successfully.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationRequest
member.summary: Container for an Operation request, which is a code and parameters.
member.remarks: On the lowest level, Photon only allows byte-typed keys for operation parameters. The values of each such parameter can be any serializable datatype: byte, int, hashtable and many more.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationRequest.OperationCode
member.summary: Byte-typed code for an operation - the short identifier for the server's method to call.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationRequest.Parameters
member.summary: The parameters of the operation - each identified by a byte-typed code in Photon.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse
member.summary: Contains the server's response for an operation called by this peer. The indexer of this class actually provides access to the Parameters Dictionary.
member.remarks:
The OperationCode defines the type of operation called on Photon and in turn also the Parameters that are set in the request. Those are provided as Dictionary with byte-keys. There are pre-defined constants for various codes defined in the LoadBalancing application. Check: OperationCode, ParameterCode, etc.
An operation's request is summarized by the ReturnCode: a short typed code for "Ok" or some different result. The code's meaning is specific per operation. An optional DebugMessage can be provided to simplify debugging.
Each call of an operation gets an ID, called the "invocID". This can be matched to the IDs returned with any operation calls. This way, an application could track if a certain OpRaiseEvent call was successful.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse.OperationCode
member.summary: The code for the operation called initially (by this peer).
member.remarks: Use enums or constants to be able to handle those codes, like OperationCode does.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse.ReturnCode
member.summary: A code that "summarizes" the operation's success or failure. Specific per operation. 0 usually means "ok".

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse.DebugMessage
member.summary: An optional string sent by the server to provide readable feedback in error-cases. Might be null.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse.Parameters
member.summary: A Dictionary of values returned by an operation, using byte-typed keys per value.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse.Item(System.Byte)
member.summary: Alternative access to the Parameters, which wraps up a TryGetValue() call on the Parameters Dictionary.
member.param: The byte-code of a returned value.
member.returns: The value returned by the server, or null if the key does not exist in Parameters.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse.ToString
member.summary: ToString() override.
member.returns: Relatively short output of OpCode and returnCode.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.OperationResponse.ToStringFull
member.summary: Extensive output of operation results.
member.returns: To be used in debug situations only, as it returns a string for each value.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData
member.summary: A Photon Event consists of a Code value and a Parameters Dictionary with the event's content (if any).
member.remarks:
The indexer of this class provides access to the values in Parameters. It wraps the null check for Parameters and uses TryGetValue() for the provided key.
Photon servers use events to send information which is not triggered by a client's operation requests (those get responses). The Realtime API allows you to send custom events with any Code and content via OpRaiseEvent.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.Code
member.summary: The event code identifies the type of event.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.Parameters
member.summary: The Parameters of an event is a Dictionary<byte, object>.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.Item(System.Byte)
member.summary: Access to the Parameters of a Photon-defined event. Custom Events only use Code, Sender and CustomData.
member.param: The key byte-code of a Photon event value.
member.returns: The Parameters value, or null if the key does not exist in Parameters.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.SenderKey
member.summary: Defines the event key containing the Sender of the event.
member.remarks: Defaults to Sender key of Realtime API events (RaiseEvent): 254. Can be set to Chat API's ChatParameterCode.Sender: 5.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.Sender
member.summary: Accesses the Sender of the event via the indexer and SenderKey. The result is cached.
member.remarks: Accesses this event's Parameters[CustomDataKey], which may be null. In that case, this returns 0 (identifying the server as sender).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.CustomDataKey
member.summary: Defines the event key containing the Custom Data of the event.
member.remarks: Defaults to Data key of Realtime API events (RaiseEvent): 245. Can be set to any other value on demand.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.CustomData
member.summary: Accesses the Custom Data of the event via the indexer and CustomDataKey. The result is cached.
member.remarks: Accesses this event's Parameters[CustomDataKey], which may be null.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.ToString
member.summary: ToString() override.
member.returns: Short output of "Event" and it's Code.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.EventData.ToStringFull
member.summary: Extensive output of the event content.
member.returns: To be used in debug situations only, as it returns a string for each value.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SerializeMethod
member.summary: Type of serialization methods to add custom type support. Use PhotonPeer.ReisterType() to register new types with serialization and deserialization methods.
member.param: The method will get objects passed that were registered with it in RegisterType().
member.returns: Return a byte[] that resembles the object passed in. The framework will surround it with length and type info, so don't include it.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SerializeStreamMethod
member.summary: Serialization method delegate. StreamBuffer based custom serialization methods must use this form.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeserializeMethod
member.summary: Type of deserialization methods to add custom type support. Use PhotonPeer.RegisterType() to register new types with serialization and deserialization methods.
member.param: The framwork passes in the data it got by the associated SerializeMethod. The type code and length are stripped and applied before a DeserializeMethod is called.
member.returns: Return a object of the type that was associated with this method through RegisterType().

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeserializeStreamMethod
member.summary: Deserialization method delegate. StreamBuffer based custom deserialization methods must use this form.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeliveryMode
member.summary: Enum of the three options for reliability and sequencing in Photon's reliable-UDP.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeliveryMode.Unreliable
member.summary: The operation/message gets sent just once without acknowledgement or repeat. The sequence (order) of messages is guaranteed.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeliveryMode.Reliable
member.summary: The operation/message asks for an acknowledgment. It's resent until an ACK arrived. The sequence (order) of messages is guaranteed.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeliveryMode.UnreliableUnsequenced
member.summary: The operation/message gets sent once (unreliable) and might arrive out of order. Best for your own sequencing (e.g. for streams).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeliveryMode.ReliableUnsequenced
member.summary: The operation/message asks for an acknowledgment. It's resent until an ACK arrived and might arrive out of order. Best for your own sequencing (e.g. for streams).

member.summary: Default SendOptions instance for reliable sending.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SendOptions.SendUnreliable
member.summary: Default SendOptions instance for unreliable sending.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SendOptions.DeliveryMode
member.summary: Chose the DeliveryMode for this operation/message. Defaults to Unreliable.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SendOptions.Encrypt
member.summary: If true the operation/message gets encrypted before it's sent. Defaults to false.
member.remarks: Before encryption can be used, it must be established. Check PhotonPeer.IsEncryptionAvailable is true.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SendOptions.Channel
member.summary: The Enet channel to send in. Defaults to 0.
member.remarks: Channels in Photon relate to "message channels". Each channel is a sequence of messages.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SendOptions.Reliability
member.summary: Sets the DeliveryMode either to true: Reliable or false: Unreliable, overriding any current value.
member.remarks: Use this to conveniently select reliable/unreliable delivery.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SupportClass.GetTickCount
member.summary: Gets the local machine's "milliseconds since start" value (precision is described in remarks).
member.remarks: This method uses Environment.TickCount (cheap but with only 16ms precision). PhotonPeer.LocalMsTimestampDelegate is available to set the delegate (unless already connected).
member.returns: Fraction of the current time in Milliseconds (this is not a proper datetime timestamp).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SupportClass.StartBackgroundCalls(System.Func{System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a background thread that calls the passed function in intervals, as long as that returns true.
member.remarks: With StopBackgroundCalls, you can stop threads started with this method. The resulting ThreadAbortException is caught and discarded.
member.param: The function to call. Must return true, if it should be called again. Returning false ends the thread.
Milliseconds to sleep between calls of myThread. Default: 100ms.
An optional name for the task to help debugging. Null or empty won't set the thread.Name.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SupportClass.StopBackgroundCalls(System.Byte)
member.summary: Calls Abort on the thread with the given id (= index of the thread list)
member.remarks: The resulting ThreadAbortException is caught and discarded.
member.param: The unique ID of the thread.
member.returns: True if the thread is canceled and false otherwise, e.g. if the thread with the given ID does not exist.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.SupportClass.StopAllBackgroundCalls
member.summary: Calls Abort on all threads that were started via StartBackgroundCalls.
member.remarks: The resulting ThreadAbortException is caught and discarded.
member.returns: True if any thread got aborted.

member.summary: Sends a ping in intervals to keep connection alive (server will timeout connection if nothing is sent).
member.returns: Always false in this case (local queues are ignored. true would be: "call again to send remaining data").

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TPeer.EnqueueMessageAsPayload(ExitGames.Client.Photon.DeliveryMode,ExitGames.Client.Photon.StreamBuffer,System.Byte)
member.summary: enqueues serialized operations to be sent as tcp stream / package

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TPeer.SendPing
member.summary: Sends a ping and modifies this.lastPingResult to avoid another ping for a while.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TPeer.ReceiveIncomingCommands(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: reads incoming tcp-packages to create and queue incoming commands*

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel
member.summary: Only in use as long as PhotonPeer.TrafficStatsEnabled = true;

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.OperationByteCount
member.summary: Gets sum of outgoing operations in bytes.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.OperationCount
member.summary: Gets count of outgoing operations.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.ResultByteCount
member.summary: Gets sum of byte-cost of incoming operation-results.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.ResultCount
member.summary: Gets count of incoming operation-results.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.EventByteCount
member.summary: Gets sum of byte-cost of incoming events.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.EventCount
member.summary: Gets count of incoming events.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.LongestOpResponseCallback
member.summary: Gets longest time it took to complete a call to OnOperationResponse (in your code). If such a callback takes long, it will lower the network performance and might lead to timeouts.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.LongestOpResponseCallbackOpCode
member.summary: Gets OperationCode that causes the LongestOpResponseCallback. See that description.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.LongestEventCallback
member.summary: Gets longest time a call to OnEvent (in your code) took. If such a callback takes long, it will lower the network performance and might lead to timeouts.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.LongestEventCallbackCode
member.summary: Gets EventCode that caused the LongestEventCallback. See that description.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.LongestDeltaBetweenDispatching
member.summary: Gets longest time between subsequent calls to DispatchIncomgingCommands in milliseconds. Note: This is not a crucial timing for the networking. Long gaps just add "local lag" to events that are available already.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.LongestDeltaBetweenSending
member.summary: Gets longest time between subsequent calls to SendOutgoingCommands in milliseconds. Note: This is a crucial value for network stability. Without calling SendOutgoingCommands, nothing will be sent to the server, who might time out this client.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.DispatchCalls
member.summary: Gets number of calls of DispatchIncomingCommands.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.DispatchIncomingCommandsCalls
member.summary: Gets number of calls of DispatchIncomingCommands.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.SendOutgoingCommandsCalls
member.summary: Gets number of calls of SendOutgoingCommands.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.TotalByteCount
member.summary: Gets sum of byte-cost of all "logic level" messages.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.TotalMessageCount
member.summary: Gets sum of counted "logic level" messages.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.TotalIncomingByteCount
member.summary: Gets sum of byte-cost of all incoming "logic level" messages.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.TotalIncomingMessageCount
member.summary: Gets sum of counted incoming "logic level" messages.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.TotalOutgoingByteCount
member.summary: Gets sum of byte-cost of all outgoing "logic level" messages (= OperationByteCount).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.TotalOutgoingMessageCount
member.summary: Gets sum of counted outgoing "logic level" messages (= OperationCount).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStatsGameLevel.ResetMaximumCounters
member.summary: Resets the values that can be maxed out, like LongestDeltaBetweenDispatching. See remarks.
member.remarks: Set to 0: LongestDeltaBetweenDispatching, LongestDeltaBetweenSending, LongestEventCallback, LongestEventCallbackCode, LongestOpResponseCallback, LongestOpResponseCallbackOpCode. Also resets internal values: timeOfLastDispatchCall and timeOfLastSendCall (so intervals are tracked correctly).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStats.PackageHeaderSize
member.summary: Gets the byte-size of per-package headers.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStats.ReliableCommandCount
member.summary: Counts commands created/received by this client, ignoring repeats (out command count can be higher due to repeats).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStats.TotalPacketBytes
member.summary: Gets count of bytes as traffic, excluding UDP/TCP headers (42 bytes / x bytes).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStats.TimestampOfLastAck
member.summary: Timestamp of the last incoming ACK that has been read (every PhotonPeer.TimePingInterval milliseconds this client sends a PING which must be ACKd).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.TrafficStats.TimestampOfLastReliableCommand
member.summary: Timestamp of last incoming reliable command (every second we expect a PING).
